title: Computing Shrines
subtext: a collection of site-specific sculptures turning shared spaces into spaces for sharing
descriptionMd:
We face a loneliness epidemic as free third spaces for communities disappear, and our devices have become symbols of isolation. Computing Shrines responds to this crisis by reimagining technology as a public good for fostering local connection rather than replacing it.
Each shrine connects visitors' phones to a custom communal web interface that facilitates the exchange of small intimacies between past and future visitors. These websites can only be accessed at their shrine, anchoring a virtual space to a physical place and turning these shrines into living archives of the collective everyday interactions of the people who steward the space.
For example, "Shrine to Voice" is mobile phone booth that invites visitors to listen to and share their worries and hopes with the last and next stranger. “Shrine to Earth” features a found boulder that invites visitors to share photos of rocks they’ve found, which become pieces in a cairn-making mini-game. And in "Shrine to Others," a clay tablet nestled beside a seating area invites visitors to notice the people they share the space with and vocalize what they admire about strangers.
Beyond an installation, Computing Shrines is an open protocol for creating public good technology that fosters local connection rather than replacing it. Designed with common materials, open-sourcing the interfaces, and collaborating with local stewards, the project transforms the normally solitary and exclusive act of creating technology into a community improvement project for all to shape.
Supported by [APOSSIBLE](https://apossible.com/), [DAL](https://dalab.xyz/en/), [NEW INC](https://newinc.org/), the New Museum’s art and technology incubator, and the San Francisco Arts Commission.
**Exhibition History**
- June 4-22: [Embodied Algorithms / Collective Mechanics](https://www.demofestival.org/showcases/art-and-code) by NEW INC and the New Museum, Curated by Sheldon Gooch
materials: location-bound websites, RFID chips, mixed materials including acrylic, ceramics, found stone, and silicone.
imageDescriptions: Shrine to Earth is a serpentine boulder that carries a website facilitating visitors offering rocks from their camera roll that they've found. Rocks are shown in a free-form physics world and can be stacked freely by visitors.

Shrine Map (Earth, Voice, Others) is an homage to community bulletin boards and uses phones and cables to represent a map of the shrines in the exhibition space. The phones play looping video showing the process and interactions of the shrines.
